I graduated from Fontbonne Hall in 1958.  Here is what was wonderful about it: I could always be exactly the person I was.  I was interested in literature and passionate about classical music (the Glee Club and piano teaching were  outstanding), and that was perfectly acceptable. I live in the south now and my book club members didn't believe me when I told them that my high school had no mean girls (except some of the nuns). I never had to feel left out by cliques or driven to be popular with boys by dimming my own light.  Nor did I ever feel that as a female I was a secondary citizen until I went to graduate school at Berkeley.  Not every teacher was wonderful at Fontbonne, but some of them were outstanding and they were all nuns, except the art and PE teacher. Some of my Latin, music, English, science and math teachers were superb.  The mansion facing the Narrows and the campus were beautiful and graduating in that white gown while carrying a dozen roses at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was a trip. My parents had to sacrifice to send me to this school, and my education enabled me to become the first person in my family to go to college; I even become a college professor. I rebelled against the rules when I was at Fontbonne, but the clarity of the moral vision eventually enabled me to find my own moral center.

Amusing how people weaned on the Apoo from the Simpsons were (and apparently, still are) left wondering why people were so offended. Indeed, many Indians speak accented English – some deeper than others, and varying by region – no news there. When my sisters and I prank called unsuspecting housewives across Zambia, where we grew up, one of the accents we used was our maths teacher Mr. Dubey's thrillingly accented English. Of course, we loved the accent, we joked about it, and…we didn’t want to be associated with it, either: that accent was one of those things marking South Asians as not ‘civilised’ enough for the transformation that was expected of us at the far reaches of Empire. While I've grown up to realise how we were trained by that same Empire to disdain our versatility with English, most others have not had the luck of chancing upon a great linguistics professor in the US(!) who showed them the light.
I wonder if the parliament has given any special award to Mr. Keishing for his distinguished 60 years of service to the country. He sure deserves one.

David's favors setting up an artifice for his columns and fitting bits of experienceand data to the traits and categories of the artifice--a clever way to expedite deceptions. Yet the tradition he is after, using the heart to see experience, to reveal the voices of the inner man (woman!), to explore the yoke and logic found inside of key contradictions, he misses because he turns the contradictions into a foil, always enabling defeat, using his natural pessissim (rather than his curiousity!) as a probe.

In contrast, the contradictions of American politics in the 19th century, nurtured and raised the inner dialogue of conscience to a highly visible public discourse. The words of the heart met reason, clashed in fierce, high debate, and exhibited physical and moral courage.

Using first person sources from abolitionists, slave brokers, women, the enslaved, poets that include Sarah Grimke, Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Archibald Grimke, Henry Laurens, Susan King Taylor, Harriet Tubman and others, I've put together "a seamless historical narrative that negates the mistruths of today's mythmakers (the words of one reader!)" thru stories of women and families that faced the physical and moral challenges and dangers of 19th century politics. If you are interested in those voices, in contrast to today, here's a link to "A Glory Over Everything:" [http://wp.me/p1mBVu-Rl]

As was learned in Congressional hearings following the economic collapse, the obscene salaries and bonuses are NOT needed to attract top talent. It was a trend that was begun back in the 1980s, when regulations began to be loosened, financial products for the secondary market created and commercial banks began to see themselves as investment banks. Then, to lure skilled traders from the then Merrill Lynches and Goldman Sachs, commercial banks began offering big compensation packages. There's no reason to continue the huge salaries but there are no truly bold, far thinking executives in charge of any of the Fortune 500 companies. They are all gutless managers, looking to squeeze the biggest short term profit out of their companies and to hell with the actual condition after they leave.

Paying for 'results' is so obviously intuitively appropriate, so easy to calculate, and so much better than paying on the basis of subjective evaluation....that it is hard to get away from.  But it doesn't necessarily induce the proper behavior.  Everyone wants to pile up enough F.U. Money that they are essentially self insured against W2 risk and can ignore results after that.

It isn't just Mr Dimon though, that is a conversation many, many companies and shareholders need to have. Why should anyone need to make $20M a year?? REALLY? It isn't even about the money by that time, but about the power which apparently comes with that size salary.

Maybe if more shareholders screamed and did not approve these huge pay packages the practice would stop. In this lifetime? I think not - the CEOs are not going to willingly give up making exponentially more than their staffs - it will need to be mandated. And since government can't do that, then the shareholders need to.

A key part of this story is the $14 million compensation paid Ina Drew last year. The average person may not be able to well articulate what is wrong with this, but they know it is not right.

In describing the eastern European country that an acquaintance of mine came from, she said: "everyone there is out to beat the system because they do not believe in the system." Does Mr. Diamond--as head of one of the most visible, influential and protected private institutions in our country--have any sensitivity to the corrosive effects on our social fabric from compensation practices like this?

As an ex senior executive deeply involved in setting compensation policy in major investment banks, I grew to realize over a long period that, for staff and executive positions particularly, trying to justify compensation based largely on performance is a misleading task. Flawed performance may not reveal itself for a long time and apparent performance success may be more a matter of market conditions or the work of the total organization and of people who have gone on before. For many staff and executive jobs including risk management, the right approach to compensation is: "what level of compensation is necessary to recruit exceptional talent to compete for the position?" Does Mr. Diamond really belive that it takes anything like $14 million year to attract well qualified, extraordinary people for the job?

It is time for Mr. Diamond to address these most fundamental questions.
